Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds William Sharpee of NC State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Dissecting the molecular mechanisms that cause Rice Blast Disease," during the summer of 2012 at Seoul National University in Seoul, Gyeonggi provence, Korea. The host scientist is Yong-Hwan Lee.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in determining at the molecular level how the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae causes Rice Blast Disease, a particularly devastating disease of rice. Current methods to control this organism are insufficient, resulting in the loss of millions of acres of rice each year. Research into how M. oryzae overcomes its host will lead to novel control methods and result in more sustainable, high yielding rice crops.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

As the world population is currently estimated at approximately seven billion people, it is impressive to imagine a population this large can be sustained by modern agriculture.  In the 1980s, the United States enjoyed a surplus of food so great that commodity prices sank and caused the farm economy to collapse.  Even as of 2003, the USDA bought surplus powdered milk to support dairy prices and prevented another collapse 1.   However, with the world population continuing to grow and recent droughts causing food prices to increase, the previous surplus of food produced by the United States has dwindled.  Droughts across the globe has the UN preparing for a possible global food crisis as corn and wheat prices have risen by 50% on international markets since June 2012 2.   In order to stem the tide of massive starvation and promote more sustainable agriculture, new technologies that increase agricultural yield must be discovered.  Of the numerous factors that hinder crop yields, plant diseases such as Rice Blast Disease caused by the filamentous fungus Magnaporthe oryzae have a devastating effect and cost growers billions of dollars annually in lost crops.  In order to discover new ways to control this disease in an economically and ecologically viable manner, research into how M. oryzae gains entry into the host plant will indicate areas of exploitation for novel control methods.

This result should not be surprising since it was shown that nucleotide diversity among 46 M. oryzae isolates was extremely low which is indicative of recent pathogen dispersal3. At the 95% nucleotide similarity threshold, none of the effectors from the M. oryzae isolates were shared among M. grisea, which is a closely related species that was included in the study. We are currently analyzing data to understand how these genes are expressed when the fungus is growing within the plant. If any of the aforementioned genes are expressed more while the fungus is residing inside the host plant, it would indicate that it must be important for infection and potentially acts as an effector. Having the opportunity to study in a world class institution such as Seoul National University was a wonderful experience.
